I used to run a small chemistry Youtube channel under spotlightman1234, its still up. I think my most popular video at one point was a method on making zinc powder through precipitation of ZnCl2 soln. For a few years in my teens I had an amazing home lab, but I live in small apartment now and I'm so limited in what I can do that I have to keep all of equipment in storage :(. I deleted a lot of my videos when I was intensely depressed for an unrelated reason, wish I still had them backed up. I used to be utterly obsessed with chemistry, but it became too painful to indulge the hobby and watch chemistry videos so I stopped for a while. Now it really saddens/worries me that my knowledge of chemistry has gotten rusty because I haven't been able to practice it for so long. I'm just catching back up with the chemistry YouTube scene and I'm happy to see how much it has grown and improved. Its also sad to see other great channels get abandoned such as myst32yt, alchemical garden, and so many others I can't recall right now. I'm struggling in college too because of my ADHD and it may be many many years before I have a place to do chemistry again. I feel lost. I almost want to quit everything and follow my passion and start making chemistry youtube videos fulltime again, but I doubt that would be sustainable and I'm concerned that I wouldn't have anything unique to offer to the YT community that your channel and many other excellent, popular, Youtube channels aren't already covering. I'm a little jealous, but more than that I'm super happy that there as many people such as yourself able to do chemistry on YouTube as there are right now and that they are being successful.

Did you think about using cyclohexene instead (about the same price and more commonly found in higher purity)? Should give the same product through dihydroxylation/diol cleavage/oxidation via tungsten catalysis.
Ozonolysis and oxidation would also give you the product in about an hour of work, but not sure now readily available the materials for that are outside of research.

Can you name the offending eBay seller? I would like to avoid them in the future.

On the other hand, dud you consider that cyclohexanone may be the contaminant? It freezes far below cyclohexanol, so it wouldn't be too unreasonable to assume cyclohexanol is crystallizing out at freezer temperature. I couldn't think of much else that would contaminate cyclohexanol, barring adulteration.

Finally, could the insoluble stuff be just residual tungstic acid left over from the oxidation? Did you also consider that the low yield may have been due to the repeated attempts at crystallization?
